vote.title: Sustaining, Deepening, and Expanding the District’s Community Schools Initiative
vote.description: Whereas, The 2019 collective bargaining agreement with United Teachers Los Angeles (UTLA) included a commitment to pilot the transformation of 30 Los Angeles Unified School District schools utilizing a comprehensive Community Schools model;Whereas, UTLA, the District, and the L.A. Compact co-convened a Community School Steering Committee (Committee), who selected a first cohort of 17 schools in 2019 and a second cohort of 13 schools who will begin their Community School transformation process in the fall of 2021;Whereas, Each school’s transformation begins with the hiring of a Community School Coordinator to lead a robust stakeholder engagement process to develop a community needs and assets assessment, through which the school identifies their top priorities for school improvement;Whereas, The Committee has identified regular check-ins with an experienced Community Schools Coach as well as monthly opportunities to engage with a Professional Learning Community as key best practices to build the capacity of the Community School Coordinator to facilitate transformational change at their school;Whereas, Community Schools are a proven effective model that have been shown to contribute significantly to higher graduation rates and to closing the racial achievement gap;Whereas, In February 2021, the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District voted to identify an additional ten schools participating in the Black Student Achievement Plan (BSAP) to begin Community School transformation in the Fall of 2021;Whereas, In April 2021, the District was awarded two California Community Schools Partnership Grants for a total of $6 million to sustain Cohort 1 community schools for an additional two years;Whereas, Governor Newsom’s 2021 May Budget Revise proposes a $3 billion investment in grants to school districts to expand the Community School model, indicating strong support for Community Schools as a model to transform educational outcomes; Whereas, Growing support and funding for the implementation of community schools across the nation, state, and region calls for a comprehensive plan to sustain, deepen, and expand the District’s Community Schools Initiative;Whereas, The Partnership for the Future of Learning’s guide to financing Community Schools finds “as community school initiatives grow, there is a need for increased systemic capacity, including staff to coordinate across individual schools, and to support planning, collecting, and analyzing data and communications” and that this “systems capacity can be supported by district staff or by a local agency acting as an intermediary”;Whereas, The Community Schools Initiative seeks to model the tenets of collaborative and distributed leadership through an infrastructure that leverages the assets of three co-convening partners, the District, UTLA, and UNITE-LA, as well as the expertise of diverse school and community leaders serving on the Community School Steering Committee; andWhereas, To ensure the successful and sustainable implementation of the District’s Community School Initiative, increased capacity and technical assistance is needed for: •	District-wide project management and coordination•	Effective engagement of important stakeholders•	Development of partnerships to expand school integration with health/mental health services, enhanced learning opportunities, and other supports•	Collaboration with the LAUSD Parent and Community Services Branch•	Professional coaching with Community Schools Coordinators•	Implementation of evaluation and continuous learning strategies; now, therefore, be itResolved, That the Governing Board of Education the Los Angeles Unified School District directs the Superintendent to deepen and expand the Community School Initiative by thoughtfully and systematically investing $10 million annually for the 40 existing and planned Community Schools and adding 10 additional schools to the Community Schools Initiative per year for three years from 2022-23 through 2024-25 with an investment of $250,000 per school per year; Resolved further, That a portion of these additional community schools shall be reserved for schools participating in the Black Student Achievement Plan, as well as adding Black student enrollment and low-income enrollment to the selection criteria for prospective community schools; Resolved further, That the District commit to funding the infrastructure necessary to sustain and expand the Community Schools Initiative established in 2019 by investing $2 million annually for project management, technical assistance, coaching, and learning and evaluation for a period of four years commencing with the 2021-2022 school year; Resolved further, That this infrastructure investment, with advisement from the Community School Steering Committee, should include: a full-time director of the Community Schools Initiative and any additional support staff required to ensure the success of the initiative; Community School Coaches, at an ideal ratio of 1 coach to 5 Community School Coordinators to support schools in their first two years of implementation; and any formalized partnerships necessary to successfully implement the Community School Initiative, such as an MOU formalizing the roles and responsibilities of the collaborative implantation team of the Community School Initiative;Resolved further, That the District ensure the Community Schools Initiative is a whole-school approach by including increased training for classified staff and inclusion of full-time community representatives;Resolved further, That the District pursue state funding for the Community Schools Initiative from the State of California, including any forthcoming funds as laid out in the Governor’s proposed budget; and, be it finallyResolved, That the District shall seek external funds to undergo an independent evaluation by the start of the 2022-23 school year to assess the impact of the existing Community Schools on student outcomes and provide recommendations for any changes, additional training, or other supports necessary to deepen the impact of the District’s Community Schools, which will be implemented as part of the initiative’s continued expansion.
